text.p: This paper contributes to the renewable energy literature from two perspectives. First, we investigate the factors driving renewable energy deployment in the MENA countries using economic, financial, and political variables including financial development, government effectiveness and political stability. This investigation is empirically carried out by the Panel Smooth Transition Model (PSTR) (Gonzales et al., 2017) that explicitly explores the threshold effect within the determinants of renewable energy production. Second, we introduce innovation as a new determinant of renewable energy deployment to account for the mediating role of technological innovation in the achievement of SDGs and especially the SDG7. Using two proxies of innovation (i.e. ICT and percentage of internet users), we show that higher innovation performance is likely to increase the impact of governance quality on renewable energy deployment. Therefore, governance quality, innovation, political stability, and financial development are the main drivers of renewable energy deployment. The paper calls for sustainable policy options that increase innovation performance and governance quality to increase the production of renewable energy.This paper contributes to the renewable energy literature from two perspectives. Second, we introduce innovation as a new determinant of renewable energy deployment to account for the mediating role of technological innovation in the achievement of SDGs and especially the SDG7. Therefore, governance quality, innovation, political stability, and financial development are the main drivers of renewable energy deployment. The paper calls for sustainable policy options that increase innovation performance and governance quality to increase the production of renewable energy.

Achieving the sustainable development goals (SDGs) with a focus on climate change mitigation, poverty reduction, and social equity is an integrated economic and political goal that involves collaboration between the public and private sectors. In particular, SDG7 aims to provide access to affordable and clean energy by promoting the production and use of renewable energy as an alternative to the extensive use of conventional polluting energy resources. Given that about two-thirds of the world's carbon emissions come from the energy sector, accelerating the implementation of low-carbon energy technologies, such as renewable energy technologies, is critical to reduce emissions (IRENA, 2017).

In recent years, rapid technological advances have been made in new renewable energy technologies, particularly in solar photovoltaics, but also wind power, bringing substantial cost reductions, increased competitiveness, system usability, and a reduced environmental footprint (IRENA, 2020). In addition, battery technologies are rapidly maturing, enabling a widespread transition to battery-powered electric mobility, as well as storage facilitating the integration of variable renewable energy into the grid. Despite the progress made worldwide in recent years, various barriers still stand in the way of large-scale deployment of green energy in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region and globally (Omri et al., 2021). As part of the efforts to reduce the risks and adverse effects of climate change and actively contribute to the mitigation of global warming in line with the Paris Climate Agreement, policymakers in developing countries in general and in the MENA region in particular are trying to diversify their energy mix by promoting the development of renewable energy. Among the critical issues, research to understand the key drivers of renewable energy deployment is of paramount importance. In this regard, existing literature using data from developing economies shows that several regulatory and institutional barriers are likely to hinder renewable energy deployment (Ahmed et al., 2021). In addition, other factors such as political stability, corruption, bureaucracy, lack of collaboration between the private and public sectors, and lack of transparency are not conducive to the development and large-scale use of renewable energy (e.g., Becker and Fischer, 2013;Bertheau et al., 2020;Hille et al., 2020;Liang and Fiorino, 2013;Miremadi et al., 2019;Sonntag-O'Brien and Usher, 2004;Tolliver et al., 2020).Despite the progress made worldwide in recent years, various barriers still stand in the way of large-scale deployment of green energy in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region and globally (Omri et al., 2021). The current study contributes to the renewable energy literature primarily from two perspectives. Firstly, we investigate the determinants of renewable energy deployment in MENA countries using economic, financial, and political variables, including financial development, governance effectiveness, and political stability. This investigation is conducted empirically by the panel smooth transition model (PSTR), which explicitly explores the threshold effect in the determinants of renewable energy generation (Gonzales et al., 2017). Secondly, we introduce innovation as a new determinant of renewable energy deployment to account for the role of technological innovation in achieving the SDGs in general and SDG7 in particular. To the best of our knowledge, there is a lack of evidence on the mediating role of innovation regarding the current state of renewable energy production in the MENA region.The current study contributes to the renewable energy literature primarily from two perspectives. Firstly, we investigate the determinants of renewable energy deployment in MENA countries using economic, financial, and political variables, including financial development, governance effectiveness, and political stability. This investigation is conducted empirically by the panel smooth transition model (PSTR), which explicitly explores the threshold effect in the determinants of renewable energy generation (Gonzales et al., 2017). Secondly, we introduce innovation as a new determinant of renewable energy deployment to account for the role of technological innovation in achieving the SDGs in general and SDG7 in particular. To the best of our knowledge, there is a lack of evidence on the mediating role of innovation regarding the current state of renewable energy production in the MENA region.

We motivate our choice of the MENA region as a case study by its ongoing structural economic and social change, with rapid economic development over the past four decades. Policymakers in the MENA region are constrained by international commitments to achieve the SDGs by 2030. Therefore, an in-depth understanding of the key factors affecting the adoption of renewable energy, including innovation, could be very useful in terms of policy options and recommendations.We motivate our choice of the MENA region as a case study by its ongoing structural economic and social change, with rapid economic development over the past four decades. To address climate change at manageable levels and achieve the sustainable development agenda set out in the Paris Agreement, a rapid and significant shift in energy investments to low-carbon technologies is needed (Amri et al., 2018;F. 2019;Belaïd, 2021;IPCC, 2014;Mongo et al., 2021a;M. 2021b).To address climate change at manageable levels and achieve the sustainable development agenda set out in the Paris Agreement, a rapid and significant shift in energy investments to low-carbon technologies is needed (Amri et al., 2018;F. 2019;Belaïd, 2021;IPCC, 2014;Mongo et al., 2021a;M. 2021b).

In recent years, the implementation of a low-carbon energy system has become one of the most essential concerns of policymakers around the world. In this context, decarbonized energy sources will undoubtedly play a crucial role not only in the long-awaited process of decarbonization of the energy mix, but also in the implementation of a new economic model, aiming to advance social welfare and sustainability (Ahmed et al., 2021;Belaïd et al., 2021a;Tiba andBelaid, 2020, 2021). However, the actual implementation of such a transition remains technically and economically complex. The recent energy economics literature has widely discussed the significant role of the renewable energy sector in achieving sustainability goals (Ahmed et al., 2021). In recent years, a considerable number of studies have emerged that can be divided into two important lines of research (Belaid et al., 2021c). The first group of studies addresses the relationship between renewable energy and macroeconomic activities, while the second focuses on the determinants of renewable energy production or consumption. With respect to the first stream, the existing literature has mainly focused on examining causal relationships between renewable and non-renewable energy consumption and economic growth (Belaid and Abderrahmani, 2013;Sadorsky, 2009). In addition, these studies have examined the relationship between energy production or consumption and environmental impacts (Apergis et al., 2010;Vural, 2020).The recent energy economics literature has widely discussed the significant role of the renewable energy sector in achieving sustainability goals (Ahmed et al., 2021). In addition, these studies have examined the relationship between energy production or consumption and environmental impacts (Apergis et al., 2010;Vural, 2020).

In a recent study using a large sample of more than 100 countries, Le et al. (2020) re-examined the dynamic link between energy consumption (renewable and non-renewable), economic growth, and greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. Their results highlight that both renewable and non-renewable energy have a significant impact on economic growth, providing evidence that renewable energy development plays a critical role in shaping economic wealth. Furthermore, the results of their study indicate that, unlike fossil fuels, the use of renewable energy helps reduce GHG emissions in developed economies but not in developing economies. This suggests that developed countries' success in controlling GHG emissions through renewable energy will have important lessons for developing nations. However, the results are contradictory between the different studies. Conflicting evidence on the interaction between the consumption of different energy sources and environmental quality can be explained by the variety of theoretical frameworks, samples, and econometric specifications adopted by researchers (Tian et al., 2021).In a recent study using a large sample of more than 100 countries, Le et al. The second emerging stream of research consists of studies that examine the drivers of renewable energy production and demand (Belaid et al., 2021c). These analyses are relatively new compared to the first stream of research (Apregis et al., 2010). The majority of existing analyses have studied the effects of several factors, including economic growth (Ahmed et al., 2021), GHG emissions, trade openness, and oil prices. Recently, some studies have begun to look beyond the standard drivers of renewable energy use and have begun to incorporate institutional quality (Chen et al., 2021). Using a panel threshold approach, Chen et al. (2021) note that democratic institutions have a significant impact on renewable energy use in a selected sample of 97 countries. In addition, some studies examine the effect of financial development on renewable energy development, suggesting that financial development is one of the main drivers of renewable energy development (Burakov, 2017;Shahbaz et al., 2021). In the context of 22 emerging economies, Wu and Broadstock (2015) examine the effects of institutional quality and financial development on renewable energy use over the period 1990-2010. They find that institutional quality and financial development have a significant positive impact on renewable energy use. The transmission mechanism from innovation to renewable energy adoption is observed through the direct or indirect effect of innovation adoption and new communication technologies on the decision to invest in renewable energy. Indeed, smart renewable energy instruments cannot be adopted without access to the internet. In addition, decisionmakers need information and communication technologies (ICT) to develop advertising and consumer awareness. Given the above discussion, this paper, as an additional contribution to the second stream of research, differs from previous studies not only by examining the context of MENA countries, but also by considering the extent to which governance quality and financial development stimulate renewable energy development. This study fills the methodological gap in renewable energy deployment by considering a threshold regression that explicitly examines the mediating role of innovation in the relationship between renewable energy and governance effectiveness (Tian et al., 2021). The traditional method by which authors test for the mediating role by introducing the square form of the mediating variable into the regression cannot clearly show nonlinear impacts (Belaid et al., 2021c;Chen et al., 2021). In addition, this paper introduces innovation as a new determinant of renewable energy deployment to consider the role of technological innovation in achieving the SDGs in general and SDG7 in particular. We use original annual panel data for nine MENA countries covering a long period from 1984 to 2014. The MENA countries considered in this study are Morocco, Tunisia, Algeria, Egypt, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Lebanon, and Yemen. We are limited by data availability when collecting panel data. We collect renewable energy production and consumption through the International Energy Agency (IEA) database. In contrast, policy and governance data are collected from the International Country Risk Guide (ICRG) database. The latter provides three risk indices by country, including political, economic, and financial risk. The political stability index and governance effectiveness were constructed using ten indicators from the ICRG database. These indicators primarily measure government stability, internal conflict, external conflict, and religious and ethnic tensions. The government effectiveness index represents the quality of public service, the independence of civil services from political pressure, and the credibility of government commitment. This governance quality index is measured by five indicators, which are the military in politics, corruption, law and order, democratic accountability, and the quality of bureaucracy. Finally, the innovation data are collected from the WDI database: they measure the growth of capital services provided by the change in information and communication technology assets and are expressed in natural log (ICT) and the percentage of internet users (ICTI). The results clearly indicate that the nonlinear model is appropriate and that the relationship between renewable energy deployment and its determinants can be described by a smooth transition regression when the two ICT measures are the transition variables.

The p-values reported in parentheses (Table 3) indicate that the nonlinear model can be represented by a single transition function across two extreme regimes (i.e., high and low regimes of innovation and technology adoption performance). We develop an innovative approach to study the determinants of renewable energy deployment in a nonlinear manner. Specifically, we study the role of innovation in the impact on renewable energy deployment performance of governance quality in the MENA region. The innovation variables (i.e., ICT adoption and percentage of internet users) drive a nonlinear relationship in the renewable energy deployment model. The results of the PSTR model presented in Table 5 are highly significant at the 1% level. It appears, as expected, that governance quality, measured by government effectiveness, positively affects renewable energy deployment. However, innovation performance increases the impact of governance quality on renewable energy when it reaches a given innovation performance threshold. Using the smooth panel transition model, the threshold level is calculated from the data. The estimated impact increases from 0.02 to 0.04 when the innovation variable measured by ICT exceeds the 0.06 threshold. However, when innovation is measured by the percentage of internet users, the impact increases from 0.027 to 0.03. As we can see, the results of the nonlinear estimation are still robust to the change in the measure of innovation. This result means that for a 1% increase in the governance quality index, there will be an increase in renewable energy production in the MENA region by 0.02%, and by 0.04% when the innovation measure exceeds the 0.06 change threshold. Furthermore, we note that when we introduce the second innovation variable (percentage of internet users) as a transition variable, the results remain robust and have the same expected sign as in the panel fixed-effect linear model. The political stability index has a positive impact on renewable energy deployment, but this impact is statistically significant only when we use the percentage of internet users as the transition variable. This positive impact of political stability confirms our intuition and the hypothesis that political stability is an important factor that can improve renewable energy production in developing countries, and particularly in the MENA region. As we saw in Section 2, political stability is closely linked to policy options for sustainable economic development. It provides real opportunities, through these sustainable policy options, to access green energy resources (Antonakakis et al., 2014). This confirms the correlation coefficient between renewable energy and financial development. Therefore, as expected, the development of the financial system is a key driver for renewable energy production. Indeed, financial development is a prerequisite and a key factor for developing research and development activities that can open up new horizons for consumer and shareholder engagement, sustainable solutions, and responsible green investment benefits. Green technologies cannot be easily developed and adopted in the absence of promising economic growth. Thus, we confirm the previous results of Sadorsky (2009), who concluded that in the case of G7 countries, an increase in real GDP could be the main driver of renewable energy consumption. Moreover, as shown by (Omri and Nguyen, 2014) for the 64-country case, the impact of economic growth on renewable energy development is closely related to the level of GDP. Moreover, the total rent (percentage of GDP) from natural resources, including oil, natural gas, coal, minerals, and forests, is used to monitor the impact of the country's dependence on natural resources. The results show that the impact is negative and significant. The availability of natural resources does not favor renewable energy deployment. This result highlights the resource curse in MENA countries. Various programs have been adopted, notably to ensure energy transition and increase renewable energy production. The specific climatic conditions of the MENA region represent an advantage for the implementation of power plants using solar energy. Solar energy is expected to meet the growing energy demand in the region. This paper has investigated the determinants of renewable energy adoption in the MENA region. We contribute to the green energy literature by testing the mediating role of technological innovation in driving the relationship between governance quality and renewable energy deployment. We use two proxies for innovation to show that higher levels of innovation should increase both governance quality and renewable energy adoption. We show that governance quality, innovation, policy stability, and financial development are the key drivers of renewable energy deployment. Accordingly, we recommend sustainable policy options that increase innovation performance and governance quality to increase renewable energy production.This paper has investigated the determinants of renewable energy adoption in the MENA region. We show that governance quality, innovation, policy stability, and financial development are the key drivers of renewable energy deployment. Accordingly, we recommend sustainable policy options that increase innovation performance and governance quality to increase renewable energy production.

Our results have several policy implications for improving renewable energy production and adoption in the MENA region. There is a clear need for specific financial instruments to stimulate investment in the adoption and development of renewable energy, particularly among small and medium-sized private investors. The study of renewable energy deployment is of critical importance to investors and policymakers. Most research articles in this literature are limited by the availability of data describing innovation and technology adoption. This paper uses aggregate data measuring the percentage of internet users and ICT usage. However, it may be interesting to conduct similar studies using disaggregated data to further investigate the role of innovation in renewable energy adoption. In addition, disaggregated data allow additional measures and proxies for innovation, which should improve the quality of the empirical investigation and allow useful policy recommendations. Future research on renewable energy deployment should estimate the same model using different types of renewables, which will be very helpful in recommending the most useful policy option. It is also important to mobilize several innovative econometric techniques when studying the link between innovation and renewable energy deployment.The study of renewable energy deployment is of critical importance to investors and policymakers.
